clean_content:
Definition / general

* Iatrogenic implantation of exogenous foreign material, specifically dental amalgam, into the tissues of the oral cavity

Essential features

* Deposition often occurs during oral procedures involving amalgam* Gray, blue or black macule on clinical exam in the oral cavity* Large black deposits or fine black granules in the connective tissue with affinity for reticulin fibers

Terminology

* Foreign body tattoo

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [M79.5](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/M00-M99/M70-M79/M79-/M79.5) - residual foreign body in soft tissue

Epidemiology

* Person with history of amalgam tooth restorations (dental fillings)* Affects 3.3% of the U.S. adult population ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))

Sites

* Any location in the oral cavity, with gingiva and alveolar mucosa being the most common location due to proximity to the teeth

Pathophysiology

* Implantation of dental amalgam into oral mucosa

Etiology

* Implantation of dental amalgam can occur several ways, including contaminated mucosal abrasion during dental procedure, broken amalgam pieces in an extraction site and endodontic retrofill procedure ([Neville: Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, 4th Edition, 2015](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1455770523/pathologyoutl-20))

Clinical features

* Gray, blue or black macule that is rarely raised* Multiple macules may occur* Borders may be well defined, irregular or diffuse* Enlargement can occur ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))* May be useful as a means for person identifications ([J Forensic Odontostomatol 1991;9:17](1814936))

Diagnosis

* In some cases, the diagnosis may be presumed on clinical exam with corresponding historical information and radiographic features* If the diagnosis cannot be made confidently on clinical exam, a biopsy is recommended for definitive diagnosis ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))

Radiology description

* Radiopaque fragments may be noted on radiographic exam if amalgam particles are large; however, this is not common

Radiology images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S. and Duane Schafer, D.D.S., M.S.  

[![Radiopaque amalgam fragments](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass01.jpg)
 
[![Radiopaque amalgam fragment](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer01.jpg)
 
[![Radiopaque amalgam fragments](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer02.jpg)

Radiopaque amalgam fragments

Prognostic factors

* Excellent prognosis

Case reports

* 38 year old woman with amalgam in mucoperiosteal flap from endodontic surgery ([J Conserv Dent 2016;19:280](27217645))* 49 year old woman with a brown-gray macule on the ventral tongue noted after dental restoration ([N Engl J Med 2016;374:e21](27119254))* 53 year old man with black macule on alveolar ridge and remote history of tooth extraction ([Indian J Med Res 2018;148:240](30381550))

Treatment

* No treatment is needed once diagnosis is established* Conservative surgical excision can be recommended for esthetic concerns, especially for the anterior maxilla ([J Esthet Restor Dent 2020;32:770](32886857))

Clinical images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S. and Duane Schafer, D.D.S., M.S.  

[![Buccal mucosa amalgam tattoo](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass02.jpg)

Buccal mucosa amalgam tattoo

[![Large maxillary amalgam tattoo](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass04.jpg)

Large maxillary amalgam tattoo

[![Alveolar ridge amalgam tattoos](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass03.jpg)
 
[![Alveolar ridge amalgam tattoos](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooSchafer03.jpg)

Alveolar ridge amalgam tattoos

Gross description

* Well defined or diffuse black, gray or blue pigmentation in connective tissue on cross section

Gross images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S.  

[![Excisional biopsy specimen](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass05.jpg)

Excisional biopsy specimen

[![Cross section](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass06.jpg)

Cross section

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Large black deposits of foreign material with or without a chronic inflammatory response in the connective tissue* Fine black granules in the connective tissue; may demonstrate affinity for reticulin fibers ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S.  

[![Extensive amalgam deposition](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass07.jpg)

Extensive amalgam deposition

[![Scattered amalgam granules](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass08.jpg)

Scattered amalgam granules

[![Around blood vessels](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass09.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass09.jpg)

Around blood vessels

  

[![Large amalgam fragment](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass10.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass10.jpg)

Large amalgam fragment

[![Giant cell engulfment](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass11.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass11.jpg)

Giant cell engulfment

Sample pathology report

* Oral cavity, excisional biopsy:
  + Foreign body tattoo (see comment)+ Comment: The histopathology and clinical information are consistent with an amalgam tattoo.

Differential diagnosis

* [Oral melanotic macule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymelanotic.html):
  + Increased melanin in basal cell layer of the epithelium with melanin incontinence in the superficial connective tissue+ Multifocal presentation may be seen in a systemic disease, such as [Addison disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/adrenaladdisons.html) or [Peutz-Jegher syndrome](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/colontumorPeutz.html) ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))* [Foreign body tattoo](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumortattoo.html) or **other exogenous material**:


    [![Lip tattoo](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass12.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityamalgamtattooGlass12.jpg)

    + Intentional tattoo pigment (shown above)+ Graphite from pencil ([Dermatol Online J 2015;21:13030](26632800))* **Drug related discolorations**:
      + Depending on the drug, histopathology features mimic those of melanotic macule or brown-yellow granules in connective tissue ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:47](30671761))* **Submucosal hemorrhage**:
        + Hemosiderin in the connective tissue from trauma+ Positive Prussian blue

Additional references

* [AAOMP: Atlas of Foreign Materials - Amalgam [Accessed 18 April 2022]](https://aaomp.org/atlas/dental-materials/amalgam/)
